Experimental Plasma Physics Data Analysis Co-op Posting

General Fusion is transforming how the world is energized by developing the first commercially-viable fusion power plant. Fusion will deliver clean, safe and on-demand power at industrial scale, providing a powerful complement to renewables and a pathway to a zero-emission grid.

Combining new technologies, proven industrial processes, and advances in fundamental fusion science, General Fusion aims to be the first in the world to develop commercial fusion power. Key performance requirements have been demonstrated at the system level, setting the stage for building a pre-commercial fusion power prototype.

Job Title: Experimental Plasma Physics Co-op
Location: Richmond BC, Canada

Start: May 2025
Term: 4, 8, 12 or 16 month placements available.

Key Responsibilities:
In this position you will participate in the development of a magnetized plasma experiment in support of General Fusion's magnetized target fusion concept. You will gain experience analyzing the dynamics of high temperature magnetized plasmas and help guide optimization of plasma injector performance by uncovering empirical trends in experimental data. You will gain experience with the measurement of plasma properties using data from magnetic probes, visible light spectroscopy, infrared interferometry, laser scattering, and x-ray diagnostics.

Typical tasks will include using existing code and software tools to examine and find trends in a large set of existing plasma data as well as writing new code to analyze experimental data in new ways. No prior experience in plasma physics is necessary, but broad mathematical problem-solving skills, basic physics understanding, and computer programming experience are required.

Relevant Skills and Experience:

Required qualifications include an aptitude for mathematical problem solving, ability to implement numerical algorithms and handle data, understanding of how to generate clear scientific plots, as well as the ability to work both independently and part of team.
A basic understanding of electromagnetism will be very helpful.

Nice to Have Skills:

Experience with Linux, Python, git, Matlab, and SQL are all additional non-required assets.


Education:

3rd or 4th year Physics, Engineering Physics, Computer Science, or Applied Mathematics
